newsitem.title: USA: Stocks down on renewed interest rate jitters.
newsitem.headline: Stocks down on renewed interest rate jitters.

text.p: Stock prices followed bonds lower Monday as Wall Street was again hounded by Friday's news of a surprisingly strong July durable goods report, which sent long-term interest rates to their highest levels in more than three weeks.

At 1 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.85 points to 5,693.89. In the broader market, declining issues beat advances 12-7 on subdued volume of 155 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite index was off 3.70 to 1,139.35 and the American Stock Exchange index slipped 0.65 to 560.29.
In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury bond was off 8/32 and its yield rose to 6.97 percent from 6.95 percent at Friday's close.
"It's a reaction to the bond market," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Co. "Certainly there's a bit more nervousness about whether interest rates will go up before the election."
Inflation-sensitive bond yields shot up to a three-week highs as July durable goods orders rose 1.6 percent, against expectations of a 0.3 percent rise.
"This is a rather jittery market if it is willing to change course on just one number," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co.
"Conviction levels are lower and therefore the market is going to be vulnerable to short-term swings," he said.
In the midst of the gloom, tobacco companies showed signs of life after the industry's victory late Friday in an Indiana liability lawsuit.

While the verdict itself was a small victory, it may provide a temporary breather for the beleaguered industry, analysts said. Philip Morris Cos. gained 3-1/4 to 91-1/4 and RJR Nabisco Holdings rose 1-1/8 to 26-5/8.
Telecommunications stocks were also very active after MFS Communications Co. and WorldCom Inc. agreed to merge, creating a fourth giant in the long-distance telephone business.
News of the deal, under which WorldCom will swap 2.1 shares for each MFS share, sent MFS soaring 10 points to 44-7/8. WorldCom shares slid four points to 22-3/8.
Analysts said the transaction was likely to heighten investor interest in the rest of the sector and telecom stocks were among the NYSE and Nasdaq most-active lists.
"This heats up the merger outlook for other telephone companies," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments.

MCI Communications, which announced that it would buy 10 billion minutes of wireless communications capacity from NextWave Telecom Inc. for resale to its own customers, rose 1/8 to 25-5/8 on volume of 2.2 million shares.
AT&T Corp. lost one point to 53-5/8 and Sprint Corp. eased 1/8 to 39-3/4, while Teleport Communications Group Inc. surged 2-1/2 to 24-3/4.
